Diogo Co(IPA-ptdiˈoɣu ˈkɐ̃w̃), inOld PortugueseDiogo Camand also known asDiego Cam,citation[[s:Encyclopædia Britannica, Ninth Edition/Angola|Angola]]''[[s:Encyclopædia Britannica, Ninth Edition|''Encyclopædia Britannica'', 9th ed.]], [[s:Encyclopædia Britannica, Ninth Edition/Volume II|Vol. II]]''BaynesThomas Spencer0Charles Scribner's SonsNew York1878{{harvid|EB|1878}}45.was aPortugalPortugueseexplorationexplorerand one of the most notablenavigatorsof theAge of Discovery. He made two voyages sailing along the west coast ofAfricain the 1480s,citationBeazleyC. Raymond[[s:1911 Encyclopædia Britannica/Cam (Cāo), Diogo|Diogo Cam (Cão)]]''[[s:1911 Encyclopædia Britannica|''Encyclopædia Britannica'', 11th ed.]], [[s:1911 Encyclopædia Britannica/Volume V|Vol. V]]''ChisholmHughPhillipsWalter Alison0Encyclopædia Britannica Co.New York1911{{harvid|EB|1911}}79.exploring theCongo Riverand the coasts of the present-dayAngolaandNamibia.
article.heading: Early life and family
article.paragraph: File:Armas Diogo Co.jpgthumbleft100pxDiogo Co's Coat of ArmsCo was born inVila Real, PortugalVila Real(some say invora), in the middle of the 15th century, ca. 1452, the illegitimate son of lvaro Fernandes or Gonalves Co,fidalgoof theRoyal Household, himself the illegitimate son of Gonalo Co. He married and had four children: Pedro Co, Manuel Co, Andr Afonso Co, and Isabel Co.
article.heading: Explorer
article.paragraph: Image:Caopillar.JPGthumb130pxleftThePadrobearing the arms of Portugal erected by Co at Cape St. MaryImage:Matadi, Congo, pedra de Ielala, Diogo Co.jpgthumb300pxStone of Ielala, with the inscriptions of Diogo CoHe was the first European known to sight and enter theCongo Riverand to explore the West African coast between Cape St. Catherine andCape Cross, almost from theequatortoWalvis Bayin Namibia.
article.heading: First voyage
article.paragraph: When KingJohn II of Portugalrevived the work ofHenry the Navigator, he sent out Co (about midsummer (?) 1482) to open up the African coast still further beyond theequator. The mouth andestuaryof the Congo had been discovered (perhaps in August 1482)and marked by aPadro, or stone pillar (still existing, but only in fragments), erected on Shark Point, attesting to the sovereignty ofPortugal; the great river was also ascended for a short distance, and intercourse was opened with the natives of theKingdom of KongoBakongokingdom. Co then coasted down along the presentAngola(Portuguese West Africa), and erected a second pillar, probably marking the termination of this voyage, at Cape Saint Mary (the Monte Negro of these first visitors).He certainly returned to Lisbon by the beginning of April 1484, when John II ennobled him, made him a cavaleiro (knight) of hishousehold(he was already an escudeiro oresquirein the same), and granted him an annuity and a coat of arms (April 8, 1484 and April 14, 1484).On his return he discovered the Island ofAnnobn.
article.heading: Second voyage
article.paragraph: File:Portuguese discoveries diogo cao.jpgthumb190pxDiogo CoThat Co, on his second voyage of 14841486, was accompanied byMartin Behaim(as alleged on the latter'sNurembergglobe of 1492) is very doubtful.But it is known that the explorer revisited the Congo and erected two more pillars beyond the furthest of his previous voyage. The first was at another Monte Negro (now Cabo Negro, Angola), the second atCape Cross. The Cape Cross pillar probably marked the end of his progress southward, some 1,400 kilometers. Co ascended theCongo RiverKongo River(which he thought led towards the realm ofPrester John), up to the neighborhood of the site ofMatadi. There, in October or November, 1485, near the falls ofYellala FallsIelala, he left an inscription engraved on the stone which testifies of its passage and that of his men :"Aqui chegaram os navios do esclarecido rei D.Joo II dePortugal- Diogo Co, Pero Anes, Pero da Costa."("Here arrived the ships of the enlightned kingJohn II of PortugalDiogo Co, Pero Anes, Pero da Costa.

According to one authority (a legend on the 1489 map ofHenricus Martellus Germanus), Co died off Cape Cross; butJoo de Barrosand others wrote of his return to the Kongo, and subsequent taking of a native envoy to Portugal. The four pillars set up by Co on his two voyages have all been discoveredin situ, and the inscriptions on two of them from Cape Santa Maria and Cape Cross, dated 1482 and 1485 respectively, are still to be read and have been printed. The Cape Cross padro is now atBerlin(replaced on the spot by a granite facsimile); those from the Kongo estuary and the more southerly Cape Santa Maria and Cabo Negro are in the Museum of the Lisbon Geographical Society.
article.heading: In literature
article.paragraph: Diogo Co is the subject ofPadro, one of the best-known poems inFernando Pessoa's bookMensagem, the only one published during the author's lifetime. He also figures strongly in the 1996 novelLord of the Kongoby Peter Forbath.
